Take refuge in these and other innumerable and boundless great bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas in the worlds of the ten directions.
Respectfully pay homage to the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and all virtuous sages.

Homage to the virtuous and wise pratyekabuddhas, homage to the virtuous and wise pratyekabuddhas, homage to the Sumeru pratyekabuddhas, homage to the Sona pratyekabuddhas, homage to the Rujha pratyekabuddhas, homage to the Upa-Rujha pratyekabuddhas, homage to the Pusya pratyekabuddhas, homage to the Go-danta pratyekabuddhas, homage to the Asrava-khinna pratyekabuddhas, homage to the Carama-atmabhAva pratyekabuddhas. I take refuge in these innumerable and boundless pratyekabuddhas.
Having paid homage to the Three Jewels, I will next repent.
Disciples!
As explained above, I have already repented of the light and heavy offenses committed against the Three Jewels. I will now further repent of the remaining offenses in order.
The Buddha said in the sutra:
There are two kinds of strong people:
First, those who do not commit offenses;
Second, those who are able to repent after committing them.
It is also said:
There are two kinds of pure dharmas that can eliminate the afflictions of sentient beings:
First, shame;
Second, remorse.
Shame means not doing evil oneself, remorse means not letting others do it. Those who have shame and remorse can be called people.
If one has no shame and remorse, one is no different from animals. Shame means being ashamed of the heavens, remorse means confessing one's transgressions to others.
Therefore, disciples, today with utmost sincerity, I am ashamed and remorseful, taking refuge in the Buddha.

Homage to the Buddha of Single Jewel Adornment in the East, Homage to the Buddha of Sandalwood Virtue in the South, Homage to the Buddha of Brahma's Voice in the West, Homage to the Buddha of Jewel Wisdom Foremost in the North, Homage to the Buddha of Lion's Marks in the Southeast, Homage to the Buddha of Jewel Canopy Illuminating the King of Emptiness in the Southwest, Homage to the Buddha of Joyful Progress in the Northwest, Homage to the Buddha of Mani Purity in the Northeast, Homage to the Buddha of Jewel Incense Supreme King in the Nadir, Homage to the Buddha of Great Renown in the Zenith. I take refuge in the Three Jewels throughout the ten directions and the entire Dharma realm.
Disciples!

From beginningless time until today, we may have believed in false and inverted views, slaughtered sentient beings, and offered them to demons, goblins, and ghosts, hoping to prolong our lives but ultimately being unable to achieve it. We may have made false statements about seeing ghosts and pretended to speak the words of spirits.
Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless. Today, we feel ashamed and reveal them to repent.
Moreover, disciples,

from beginningless time until today, we have either acted arrogantly, prideful, self-important, or relied on our family background to look down on everyone, using our status to deceive the humble, our strength to oppress the weak, our wealth to look down on the poor, our official position to be arrogant towards inferiors, or drinking alcohol, fighting, and causing chaos without avoiding relatives or strangers, intoxicated all day long without recognizing superiors or inferiors.
Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless. Today, we sincerely confess and repent.

We may have been greedy, lazy, and ignorant of shame, craving food and drink without regard for hardship, drinking alcohol, eating meat, singing, dancing, and making music without any sense of moderation or knowing when to rest.

We may have eaten raw fish, consumed the five pungent roots, and polluted scriptures and images, pushing aside the pure assembly, indulging our minds and acting unrestrained to the extreme, neglecting good people and befriending bad friends.

Or being arrogant, deceitful, stubborn, and self-willed, rough and rude, not understanding human feelings, oneself right and others wrong, oneself good and others bad, seeing others' faults and attacking them, fabricating phrases in hopes of good fortune.
Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless. Today, with utmost sincerity, I take refuge and repent.
Or, when it comes to money, not yielding, lacking integrity and shame, butchering meat, selling alcohol, deceiving to make a living;
Or, calculating the profits and losses of investments, selling time and days, hoarding and being stingy, greedily seeking without satiation, receiving offerings from others without feeling ashamed;
Or, lacking precepts and conduct, empty-handed accepting offerings of faith;
Or, beating slaves and servants, driving young people, not caring about hunger and thirst, not knowing about cold and heat;
Or, dismantling bridges and roads, blocking and cutting off passage.
Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless. Today, with utmost sincerity, I take refuge and repent.

Or, being unrestrained and heedless, we engage in meaningless distractions, playing games like go, chess, and backgammon, gathering in groups, drinking alcohol, eating meat, and making sarcastic remarks to each other.

We discuss worldly affairs from month to year, wasting our days in vain, not practicing meditation or chanting in the early, middle, or late periods of the night, being lazy and indolent, lying down all day long.

Our minds are not focused on the six recollections, and when we see others' superior achievements, we give rise to jealousy, harboring malicious thoughts and giving rise to afflictions, causing the fierce winds of evil to blow, the fire of evil fuel to blaze uncontrollably, and the slightest wholesome karma of the three karmas to be completely burned. When wholesome dharmas are exhausted, we become icchantikas, falling into the fire hell without any hope of escape.
Therefore, disciples!
Today, with utmost sincerity, we bow our heads before the assembly of Buddhas and sages in the ten directions, repenting of all the various offenses we have committed above.

Whether light or heavy, coarse or fine, whether done by oneself, instructed to others, rejoiced in, or forced to do so by power, up to praising the practice of evil dharmas, today I confess and repent with utmost sincerity, wishing for all to be eradicated.

May the disciples, relying on the merit born from repenting of all evils, wish to be kind, harmonious, loyal, filial, humble, self-abasing, knowing shame and modesty, inquiring first with a sincere mind, virtuous, honest, pure, righteous, and yielding, staying far away from bad friends, always encountering good conditions, restraining and guarding the six sense faculties, respectfully protecting the three karmas, enduring hardship and suffering without a retreating mind, establishing the resolve for enlightenment and bearing the burden for sentient beings, in life after life, world after world.
The Sutra of the Questions and Answers of the Mahayana Lotus Treasure-Reaching Monk on Retribution, Treasure-Reaching Previously Entered the Hell of Fire Spears.
Why is it called the Hell of Fire Spears?
The hell is one hundred and fifty yojanas long and wide, surrounded by iron walls that are fiercely blazing.
The ground gives birth to spears that pierce the sinners, entering from the soles of their feet and exiting from the tops of their feet. The sinners wail and cry out in pain.
In the southern gate, there are five thousand monks who cry out, saying:
What sins have we committed to come and enter here?
The horse-headed rakshasa seizes a trident with his hand and jabs it into their backs, coming out through their chests.

When the sinners enter the hell, iron spears come and pierce their feet, and the flames and smoke burn through their chests and hearts. For one day and one night, they experience ten thousand kinds of suffering. They die a thousand times and are reborn a thousand times, dying ten thousand times and being reborn ten thousand times. If they obtain a human body, it will be incomplete.
Baota asked the horse-headed rakshasa:
What evil karma did these monks create to come and enter here, suffering like this?
The horse-headed rakshasa replied to Baota Bodhisattva, saying:

Here, monks who have received the Buddha's pure precepts do not guard their dignified conduct. They wear boots and shoes to the toilet without taking them off, stepping on the Buddha's ground and the Sangha's ground with their feet, or stepping on the shadows of Buddha images and stupas. Because of these causes and conditions, they receive such punishments.
Baota heard this and wept as he left.Here is the corrected and aligned text:
